comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Low quality copy of four A-6A Intruder in gull gray and white with black radomes probably flying in formation for a publicity shot during or after August 1966. Tail code NJ of VAH-123 “Professionals” across gold band and black striping on vertical tail. Nearest to furthest most recognizable are; Bu No 152921 Modex 813 Bu No 152913 Modex 814 Bu No 152934 Modex 801 ? Below is seen the roadway of Highway 20 snaking across two bridges called Deception Pass Bridge over a central islet called Pass Island within a rugged wooded coastal scene, a few miles north of Naval Air Station Whidbey Island along the north western US state of Washington. (location identified from study of “Google Earth”) VAH-123 was established 1957 and disestablished 1971. Based at NAS Whidbey Island, Washington State. The ‘Pros’ were originally the Pacific Fleet's Replacement Air Group/Fleet Replacement Squadron for the A-3 Skywarrior and provided training services for the Pacific Fleet A-6 community for about one year until the establishment of VA-128 ‘Golden Intruders’ in 1967. Info on VAH-123 within this Intruder Association webpage: www.intruderassociation.org/squadrons/va128.html ………………………………………………………………………………………….... A-6A/KA-6D 152921 served the US Navy right through to 1993. Flickr pic of BU No 152921 when a KA-6D: www.flickr.com/photos/30274005@N05/3707740619/ Reference to A-6A/KA-6D 152921 www.vvmf.org/thewall/anClip=79877 KA-6D 152921 was retired to the desert boneyard at the then AMARC on April 8 1993 with AMARC inventory code AN5A0063. By going to this website "AMARC III": www.amarc.info/ Mouse clicking on 'Inventory by type', scroll down to box 'A-6 Intruder', mouse click on it and the most up to date inventory list may be viewed. An inventory dated 26 March 2011 recorded 163 A-6 still in storage at what is now 309th AMARG. (A list dated 14 September 2010 included 174 A-6 Intruder) Because of recent precautionary restrictions on information only the minimum details of aircraft at AMARG are now allowed to be published. All aircraft in all "AMARC III" lists are now in arrival date order only. KA-6D 152921 arrival date was 8th April 1993 and is no longer is on that list, thus may now be disposed of for scrap. ………………………………………………………………………………………….... A-6A/KA-6D 152913 served the US Navy until its as yet unknown end. 1968 picture of A-6A 152913 with VA-75 ‘Sunday Punchers' as Modex 501: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A-6A_VA-75_landing_on_USS... 1970-1972 ‘flickr’ pic of KA-6D 152913 with VA-65 ‘Tigers’ as Modex 422: www.flickr.com/photos/18532986@N07/4686235073/ A-6A/KA-6D 152913 was probably scrapped at a Naval Air Depot. ………………………………………………………………………………………….... A-6A/KA-6D 152934 served the US Navy through to 1984. 1982 record for KA-6D 152934 with VA-75 'Sunday Punchers' as Modex 513: www.gonavy.jp/CVW3-AC1982.html CVW-3 (AC) CV-67 JOHN F.KENNEDY January 4 to July14, 1982 (Mediterranean Sea & Indian Ocean voyage) KA-6D 152934 was with VA-75 'Sunday Punchers' as Modex 513 when it crashed into the Gulf of Mexico after loss of control during launch from carrier USS John F. Kennedy on July 12, 1984 – crew ejected, hopefully……safely: www.ejection-history.org.uk/aircraft_by_type/a6_prowler.htm (scroll down using slider on right to view records in chronological order) 1984 record for KA-6D 152934 with VA-75 'Sunday Punchers' as Modex 513: www.gonavy.jp/CVW3-AC1983-1.html CVW-3 (AC) CV-67 JOHN F.KENNEDY April 26 to July 1, 1983 (NorLant exercise cruise)
